article.Heading: Budget 2016: ONGC sinks 10% on 20% ad valorem cess, no custom duty lifts HPCL
article.Summary: Oil marketing companies gained due to non-imposition of custom duty on crude oil imports. HPCL rallied over 4 percent followed by BPCL and IOC with marginal gains.
article.Body:
Moneycontrol Bureau

Shares of Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC) was the biggest loser on Sensex, losing 10 percent to Rs 194.10 at close on Monday after the government made changes in a cess levied on domestically produced crude oil.

While presenting Union Budget 2016, Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said the government reduced cess on domestically produced crude oil from Rs 4500 per metric tonne to 20 percent ad valorem.

JP Morgan says 20 percent ad valorem results in only around USD 2 a barrel reduction in cess.

According to the brokerage, current environment remains negative. Even after today’s 10 percent share price fall, the stock does not fully capture the current stressed environment, JP Morgan feels.

Another reason that pushed stock lower was non-imposition of custom duty on crude oil.

As international oil prices slumped to 12-year lows, the domestic industry was widely anticipating re-imposition of 5-percent customs duty on crude oil imports.

In June 2011, when rates zoomed to over USD 140 per barrel, the customs duty on crude oil imports had been cut to zero from 5 percent.

However, oil marketing companies gained due to non-imposition of custom duty on crude oil imports. HPCL rallied over 4 percent followed by BPCL and IOC with marginal gains.

Posted by Sunil Shankar Matkar
